title: Division on the Soroban: The Inverse of Multiplication
description: Division is the most advanced basic operation. Here's how the soroban handles it, and when your child might be ready.

content.intro: Division on the soroban is the most complex basic operation, but it follows logical patterns. It's essentially figuring out "how many times does this fit?" while tracking remainders – something the soroban visualizes beautifully.

sections.text: Division is advanced. Your child should first be comfortable with:

items: Multiplication (at least single digit × single digit)

sections.text: Soroban division asks: "How many times does the divisor fit into this portion of the dividend?" Track that count, subtract, repeat.

items: Ask: How many times does 2 fit into 8?
Set 15 on the soroban (1 in tens, 5 in ones)
Start with tens: 1 (ten) ÷ 3 doesn't go evenly
**Visualizes the process:** Kids SEE the dividend shrinking as they subtract
**Tracks remainders:** The remaining beads show what's left
**Builds estimation:** "How many times does this fit?" becomes intuitive
**Prepares for long division:** Same concepts, but with physical manipulation

sections.text: Don't rush to division. Strong multiplication skills make division much easier. Master times tables first.

items: After 4-6 months of soroban practice minimum
When times tables (at least 1-9) are solid
When the child shows confidence and interest

faq.question: Is division necessary on soroban?
faq.answer: Not for everyone. Many kids benefit greatly just from addition/subtraction and multiplication. Division is optional but rewarding for those who pursue it.

faq.question: Can kids do long division on soroban?
faq.answer: Yes! The same principles scale. It's actually easier to understand long division after learning it on the soroban because the place value concepts are concrete.

faq.question: How long does it take to learn division?
faq.answer: After a foundation in multiplication, basic division takes 1-2 months. Complex division with remainders and decimals takes longer.

cta.text: Our app introduces division when your child has built the foundation.
